ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broader knowledge of the role of the physicians wife, her advocacy work, and how she was influenced by her spouse. Additional study of the marriage as an institution, sex and gender, and the patient-physician relationship.
I learned so much in this course! Actually such an amazing and important course.

how marriage has been viewed in society over time/by the medical establishment
differences in heterosexual vs homosexual marriages
analyzing marriage for people in relationships with medical professionals
Finding primary historical and secondary resources, analyzing primary and secondary historical resources, taking a gender + racial critical eye to piece of literature

I learned how to look for and analyze primary sources and then also use secondary sources to form an argument. It was interesting to explore the biases of an author and how this affects the information we have today and how we perceive certain subjects/people.
insights into the institution of marriage, improved understanding of postwar American life, primary source analysis and research

I learned a lot more about the context of the medical field and the ways in which medicine is shaped by cultural ideas of gender and relationships. I also practiced a lot of archival research skills and learned a lot about different kinds of historical writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lovely reading assignments and writing assignments. I always felt incredibly engaged with the work we were doing and seminars were full of interesting primary sources analyses, intimate discussions, and reflection.  No weaknesses!

strengths: professor, readings, assignments
weaknesses: none

Strengths: I do like the structure of having to contribute discussion questions weekly and the series of small assignments. Additionally, I thought the readings were an amazing selection. If anything, Id like to potentially see more primary sources (if possible??) from women/POC, but the class does quite a good job of representing these viewpoints in the secondary literature. 

Weaknesses: I think that students in the class were often quiet, leading to quite an uneven set of contributions (myself included... students like me sometimes talk a little too much in the silence!). I wonder if there could be smaller individual assignments (like maybe a 10 minute opener?) to engage more of the class more regularly.
I felt like we jumped around a lot each week and sometimes it was hard to follow where we were going and why.

Strengths: easy to communicate with classmates and professor and each week we had really interesting conversations and readings.

Weaknesses: seminar feels a bit long and draining sometimes. Some of my other seminars had a 5 min break in the middle of class, and I found this to be extremely helpful in terms of engagement and just resetting.

Professor O'Donnell, her witty teaching style,  enthusiasm and expertly curated syllabus are the course's strengths!! 

No weaknesses :)

Strength - interesting material 
Weakness - lack of discussion among peers, it felt like everyone was talking to the Professor rather than each other

Overall this was a very good class! I thought the readings the first couple of weeks were a little boring but for the whole rest of the semester, the readings and discussions were very interesting. I also think Professor O'Donnell is a great professor and was very supportive. I really enjoyed the topic and our conversation. I would've liked more feedback on our essays but that's a small critique.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Of course. Not only is the course amazing, but any chance one gets to take a course with Professor ODonnell is a blessing. ODonnell is kind, caring, and wants her students to grow. She challenges them to think about course concepts in new ways and puts a lot of emphasis on historical skill development.
YES. Amazing course, such important material! Relevant to today too
Yes, definitely - it was super interesting and engaging and professor odonnell is great
Absolutely. If someone is interested in medicine, gender, and sexuality, even a little bit, this class is for them. Professor O'Donnell is a gem and you need to take a class from her!!!

Yes definitely. If you have taken classes like the History of Reproductive Health, then there is a bit of overlap but its interesting to apply and discuss this information in a seminar format. The seminar may have been very different if there had been more make voices, as our class was entirely composed of female-presenting students.
Yes, absolutely, 10000%.
Yes, I love O'Donnell. She's a great teacher. Highly recommend her.
I would definitely recommend! Professor O'Donnell creates a really lovely classroom environment and I think the topic is very interesting.
